topic.title: Cable Auto Detection Description

body.p: Switchtec supports cable automatic detection to distinguish between different types of cable. If cable auto-detection is enabled in the configuration file for a specific PCIe Connector, Switchtec ports using that connector will be able to dynamically adapt to cable type changes.
Generally, the switch hardware supports two main port modes:

Port mode can be selected in two ways, static and dynamic. The initial port mode can be chosen by configuring Configuration File field "Enable PCIe Optical Support" per port. This field determines the port mode to adopt after Switchtec completes its boot cycle. If Cable Auto Detection is not enabled to one port, the port mode and cable type will be fixed and cannot be changed. If the "Cable Auto Detect Enable" field in the connector instance binding to a physical port is enabled, then the port will dynamically adjust to differing cable types.

Currently Switchtec only supports SFF-8636 compatible cables to perform cable detection. Switchtec distinguishes cable type by reading an embedded SEEPROM in the cable through the TWI interface. Transmitter Technology field (Byte147, bit[7:4], SEEPROM of cable compatible with SFF-8636) indicates the cable type. In SFF-8636, the cable is divided into 3 types: passive copper cable, active copper cable and active optical cable. The definition which depends on Transmitter Technology is as following:

Please note in the Switchtec design, cables with a value of "0x0-0x7, 0x9" in Transmitter Technology field are regarded as active optical cables since they need hardware to enable optical mode. For cables which don't have an in-cable SEEPROM, Switchtec has a cable type detection retry mechanism. In two seconds after PRESENCE is triggered, Switchtec will read the SEEPROM every 100ms. After 20 retries, if the SEEPROM in cable is still unreadable, the cable will be declared as a passive copper cable.

The cable auto detection feature relies on standard PCIE Hotplug mechanisms. Cable presence and adapter presence are "ANDed" and share the same input "Device Present Status" signal of the connector. "1" indicates present and "0" indicates not present. When "Device Present Status" changes from "1" to "0", the Switchtec regards it as PCIE device removal. When "Device Present Status" changes from "0" to "1", Switchtec regards it as PCIE device add.

For scenarios where a port is composed of multiple cables, the user has to define a primary cable and route that cables PRESENCE to the PCIe Connector "Device Present Status" signal. Switchtec cable auto detection feature only relies on the primary cable. It is important to maintain similar, if not identical, cables types, lengths and vendors when defining a port that spans multiple cables.

note.p: For cable Hot Plug, it is recommended to plug out all old non-primary cables before the primary cable and plug in all non-primary cables before the primary cable.
When cable auto-detection is intended, the PCIe Connector which enables the feature must be bound to the first lane in the port definition (upstream or downstream).

Connector type SFF-8639 supports both "Device Present Detect Status" and "Device Interface Detect" signals to detect drive presence and drive type. However, if Cable Auto Detection is enabled in a connector instance, user has to define "Device Present Detect Status" signal and mark "Device Interface Detect" as "Unused".

body.p: For Active cables, an additional GPIO connector pin is required: Vact Power. This GPIO is defined in the PCIe Connector Settings block under the name "Vact Power Control GPIO Index". The switch uses this field to dynamically control Vact Power in the active cable. If this field is configured with a valid GPIO index, then switchtec will disable power to Vact on plug out and enable power to Vact on plug in.
